description:
Plasmodium sp. gorilla clade G1 is a species of malaria parasite that primarily infects western lowland gorillas (Gorilla gorilla gorilla) in Central Africa. It is a member of the Plasmodium genus, which includes several species of protozoan parasites that cause malaria in various vertebrate hosts.

The Plasmodium sp. gorilla clade G1 is genetically distinct from other Plasmodium species that infect humans, chimpanzees, or other primate species. Phylogenetic analyses have shown that it belongs to a clade of Plasmodium parasites that are specifically adapted to infect western lowland gorillas.

The life cycle of Plasmodium sp. gorilla clade G1 is similar to that of other Plasmodium species, involving both sexual and asexual stages in the mosquito vector and the vertebrate host. However, the specific details of its transmission, pathogenesis, and impact on the health of western lowland gorillas are still under investigation.

Understanding the biology and ecology of Plasmodium sp. gorilla clade G1 is important for better understanding the evolution and diversity of malaria parasites, as well as for developing effective conservation strategies for the endangered western lowland gorilla population.
